en: Le Puits Ricard is classified as a Historic Monument. A realistic retrospective of the world of the Black Mouths and the history of the La Grand'Combe mining basin. La Maison du Mineur paints a picture of the miner's work. The buildings of washbasins, showers, machinist's rooms, generators, workshops or the headframe of the Ricard Well are all part of the moving discovery of this amazing heritage.the visit begins with the building of the washbasins showers, a symbolic place of the time of the mine, which dates from 1935. In the past, in the "hanging room", there were 1800 baskets hoisted to the ceiling by means of a chain. A numbered basket was assigned to each miner when he was assigned to the mine. In this basket, the miner stored his clothes at the beginning and end of his work. In this large room, you can discover the collections of photos, fossils, firedamp, lamps, background materials, extraction cables, bricks and pebbles of coal, surveyors' plans and the reconstruction of the miner's habitat at the beginning of the century. Here, we touch the daily life of the miner. Nothing is faked. Outside the miner's house you can see the workshops where the miners used to deposit their equipment to be repaired. Outside the miner's house you can see the workshops where the miners left their equipment to be repaired, including a forge, an electrical workshop, a shop and a mechanical workshop. The Puits Ricard is classified as a Historic Monument. It allowed the descent of the "cages" to a depth of 801 metres. This well, the deepest in the whole basin, was built between 1932 and 1935 and closed in 1978. Next to the metal headframe, reinforced with concrete after the fire in the Ricard shaft, the rocking building of the saloon cars has been preserved. The saloon cars came out of the shaft and were directed towards the tumbling building by inclined tracks to empty the coal. It fell into a hopper in the basement and was directed to the processing workshops by conveyor belt.open Tuesday to Sunday and holidays - except May 1 and November 1. en:
The Puits Ricard is classified as a historical monument.

A realistic retrospective of the world of the "gueules noires" and the history of the La Grand'Combe mining basin. The Maison du Mineur (Miner's House) paints a picture of the miner's work. The washroom and shower buildings, the machinist's rooms, the generators, the workshops and the Ricard shaft headframe are all part of the moving discovery of this amazing heritage.

The visit begins with the shower room building, a symbolic place from the time of the mine, which dates from 1935. In the past, in the "hanging room", there were 1,800 baskets hoisted to the ceiling by means of a chain. Each miner was given a numbered basket when he was assigned to the mine. In this basket, the miner stored his clothes at the beginning and end of his work. In this large room, you can see collections of photos, fossils, firedamp, lamps, underground equipment, mining cables, bricks and coal pebbles, surveyor's plans, as well as a reconstruction of the miner's home at the beginning of the century. Here, we get a first-hand look at the miner's daily life. Nothing is fake. Everything is period, saved in extremis from oblivion.
Outside the Miner's House you can see the workshops where the miners used to leave their equipment to be repaired. In the past there was a forge, an electrical workshop, a shop and a mechanical workshop.

The Puits Ricard is classified as a historical monument.
It is very impressive in itself. It allowed the descent of the "cages" to a depth of 801 meters. This well, the deepest in the whole basin, was built between 1932 and 1935 and closed in 1978. Next to the metal headframe, which was reinforced with concrete after the Ricard shaft fire, the building where the saloon cars were tumbled has been preserved. The berlines came out of the shaft, were directed towards the tumbling area by inclined tracks to empty the coal. It fell into a hopper in the basement and was directed to the processing shops by conveyor belt.

Open Tuesday to Sunday and public holidays - except May 1 and November 1.

Opening hours are :
March 1 to June 30 and September 1 to December 20:
from 9:30 am to 12:00 pm and from 2:30 pm to 5:30 pm
The last visit leaves at 4pm
In July and August
from 9am to 12pm and from 3pm to 6.30pm
Departure of the last visit at 5pm
Duration of the visit: 1h30.

On the program this summer :
A sound and light show is scheduled this summer, on Thursdays 20 and 27 July and Thursdays 3, 10 and 17 August at the Puits Ricard
On this occasion, a dramatized visit and an animation will be proposed - admission 5 €
